comment.author: 13423385@N03
comment._content: I think here that Kiladyulu is Mount Kiladzulu, or Chiradzulu.

comment.author: 59356674@N05
comment._content: I wonder why so many people climbed a relatively obscure mountain (it's near Chileka, the airport that serves Blantyre). Is that some sort of surveying table in the background? I notice there's one white person, possibly a surveyor.

comment.author: 59356674@N05
comment._content: I think the sticks they're carrying were to slash paths through the bush, since it's very entangled there.

comment.author: 59352877@N05
comment._content: At 6000 feet hardly an insignificant hillock?  Anyway the picture certainly shows a survey party and I'd like to say the white man was Mr Anderson, Chief Surveyor who died 1900 however there is a picture of Mr Anderson at CO 1069-109-34 and one contributor Michael J Watt has more information about him and its not the same man - shame we are not likely to have anyone alive now that can identify the chief surveyor pictured or the many Malawians assisting the British Empire map out "their" domains!

comment.author: 60406173@N04
comment._content: The summit of Chiradzulu, on the east side of the Limbe-Zomba road, is at 5821 feet (1773 metres) above sea level, but its base is already at some 4000 feet above sea level, which makes it, at less than 2000 feet base to top, about the size of an English Lake District “mountain”.  As to the mountain near Chileka, perhaps Sinyala was thinking of Michiru.
